content.question: Which of the following graphs predicts the most likely rate of the enzyme-catalyzed reaction if the concentration of the enzyme in the mixture were doubled?

choices.label: The figure shows the graph of a curve in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Substrate Concentration, in micromolar,” and the numbers 0 through 1,000, in increments of 200, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Product Produced After 5 Minutes, in micromoles,” and the numbers 0 through 240, in increments of 40, are indicated. The curve begins at the origin and moves upward and to the right at a near constant rate, passing through the point with coordinates 100 comma 50. It begins to level off, passing through the point with coordinates 200 comma 60, after which it continues horizontally to the right until the end of the horizontal axis.

The figure shows the graph of a curve in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Substrate Concentration, in micromolar,” and the numbers 0 through 1,000, in increments of 200, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Product Produced After 5 Minutes, in micromoles,” and the numbers 0 through 240, in increments of 40, are indicated. The curve begins at the origin and moves upward and to the right at a near constant rate at first, passing through the point with coordinates 100 comma 120 and continuing upward and to the right to the point with coordinates 200 comma 240. It then levels off rapidly and continues horizontally to the right until the end of the horizontal axis.

The figure shows the graph of a curve in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Substrate Concentration, in micromolar,” and the numbers 0 through 1,000, in increments of 200, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Product Produced After 5 Minutes, in micromoles,” and the numbers 0 through 240, in increments of 40, are indicated. The curve begins at the point with coordinates 0 comma 10 and moves upward and to the right, passing through the point with coordinates 200 comma 30. It then curves sharply upward and slightly to the right, passing through the point with coordinates 300 comma 180. It continues upward and to the right through the point with coordinates 400 comma 220, after which it levels off and continues horizontally to the right until the end of the horizontal axis.

The figure shows the graph of a curve in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Substrate Concentration, in micromolar,” and the numbers 0 through 1,000, in increments of 200, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Product Produced After 5 Minutes, in micromoles,” and the numbers 0 through 240, in increments of 40, are indicated. The curve begins at the origin and moves upward and to the right at a near constant rate at first, passing through the point with coordinates 100 comma 60 and then through the point with coordinates 200 comma 120. It then levels off, and continues horizontally, passing through the point with coordinates 550 comma 120, after which it moves downward and to the right until the point with coordinates 700 comma 60. It then continues horizontally to the right until the end of the horizontal axis.

content.answer: The figure shows the graph of a curve in the first quadrant of a coordinate plane. The horizontal axis is labeled “Substrate Concentration, in micromolar,” and the numbers 0 through 1,000, in increments of 200, are indicated. The vertical axis is labeled “Product Produced After 5 Minutes, in micromoles,” and the numbers 0 through 240, in increments of 40, are indicated. The curve begins at the origin and moves upward and to the right at a near constant rate at first, passing through the point with coordinates 100 comma 120 and continuing upward and to the right to the point with coordinates 200 comma 240. It then levels off rapidly and continues horizontally to the right until the end of the horizontal axis.

skill.text: 3.B: State the null hypothesis or predict the results of an experiment.
